text: At yesterday’s grand opening of Meritus Commons, it was my pleasure to present a certificate to the advocates who made it all possible. @MeritusHealth and their School of Osteopathic Medicine went above and beyond, bringing a new generation of healthcare professionals to Hagerstown and ensuring that those students have a designated, residential space to study and live. I cannot wait to see these future doctors grow and serve the patients they’ve dedicated their careers to helping.

It’s always amazing to be a part of the annual Poolesville Day “Fair Access” breakfast. Over coffee and delicious food, I heard their needs — the MD Agriculture Reserve and our rural communities deserve equal access to high-speed broadband, infrastructure, quality health care, and adequate transportation options.  
 
Progress is being made by this close-knit community — their care and support for one another makes real results for them all.  I look forward to working with Poolesville community leaders and our local officials in the year ahead!

Our federal workers keep this country running — their work is essential, selfless, and too often unseen. I sat down with @AFSCME, the largest union of U.S. public workers, and @AFSCMEMaryland President Patrick Moran to discuss the Big Budget Bill. The institutions under attack were built by their hard work — roundtable discussions like this one not only highlight our shared values, but also spark collaboration on every level of government to defend our public servants and the Americans they pledge to protect.

I visited the Beltsville Agricultural Research Center yesterday — a global leader in science and home to the nation’s preeminent Bee Lab. This irreplaceable hub of agricultural research has been slated for closure by the administration. 

From crop testing to training the next generation of scientists, the work done here is vital. Decades of taxpayer-funded research and the strength of Maryland’s 83,000 farms are on the line. This centerpiece of innovation cannot be shuttered without congressional approval —  and I’ll fight to protect it.

As a communications lawyer and longtime nonprofit advocate, the suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s show was jarring.  Freedom of speech, and of our press, underpins our democracy and who we are as Americans. 

Witnessing the FCC — an independent government agency — being weaponized to suppress speech critical of this Administration is unfathomable to me, and should be to all who believe in serving the public interest.  Without a free and independent media, the 4th branch of government, no one will know or speak out about injustice.

Our networks, regulators, and cultural institutions don’t just deliver content — they safeguard our ability to question or dissent. We must use this moment to recommit to protecting those freedoms, but also to protecting our country and its institutions.  And, this is one pivotal issue from which I will not back down.

September is Suicide Prevention Month—a time to remember that reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Too many families here in our district and across Maryland have felt the heartbreak of losing someone to suicide. We must break the stigma and remind one another that no one has to face their struggles alone. If you or someone you know needs support, dial 988—help is here, and hope is real.

The working families and treasured businesses in my district are grappling with a slew of devastating cuts by this Administration, but us Marylanders have something they can't break: community. I fought to get those doors reopened, but it should have never happened in the first place.

Farmers share their most personal financial details when applying for @USDA loans and disaster aid. As a farmer's daughter, I know this isn’t just paperwork—it’s people’s lives and livelihoods. But that trust was broken when DOGE gained access to USDA systems.

That’s why I introduced the Protecting Agricultural Borrower Information Act—to ensure sensitive data stays protected by vetted USDA staff, not outside projects or third parties.

We must restore accountability and safeguard the bond of trust between citizens and their government.

It was my privilege to speak at today’s Alabaster House Leadership Summit, where I joined veterans, faith leaders and some of my colleagues in Congress to discuss how we lead in times of crisis. The threat political violence poses to our democracy doesn’t follow party lines — when chaos threatens to divide us, we must remember that only through unity can we come back stronger. 

Our country was built on common ground: stewardship and service to one another. When we protect that foundation, we protect each other — and every American is better for it.

A few days ago, my team joined neighbors in Hagerstown for the annual 9/11 remembrance ceremony. Standing before a piece of wreckage from that day is a powerful reminder of the lives lost, the heroism shown and the unity we found in one another in Maryland and across the country.

As we honor the fallen, we also carry that spirit forward—reaching out, listening and strengthening our bonds here at home.

Today marks 24 years since September 11, 2001. We remember the lives lost and honor the first responders who rushed into danger to save others. We will never forget, and we hold on to the unity and resilience that helped us through those dark days.

One important lesson from that day was the critical need for first responders to have effective communication tools in a crisis. That need led to the creation of FirstNet, a nationwide broadband network built specifically for public safety, which I was honored to help create. Now, when every second counts, our firefighters, police, and EMTs can stay connected and save lives.

On this anniversary, I join our country in taking a moment to reflect, remember, and thank those who continue to protect our communities every day. We will never forget.

I’m deeply saddened to learn of another act of gruesome gun violence—a grim punctuation point on how fractured we are as people in this country.  The increasing intolerance, rage and politically motivated violence must halt. I have long held that I would not want to live in a country where everyone thought like me, looked like me or worshipped like me—that is not America and our differences make us stronger. 

No matter who you are, you should never fear for your life because of your beliefs or circumstance.  We are better than this.  I send my deepest sympathy to Charlie Kirk’s loved ones, and prayers for his survival.

Recently, I had the pleasure of sitting down with the Town of Lonaconing's Mayor Jack Coburn and other town officials for lunch. The homemade dip and chicken salad sandwiches were delicious, but what was most touching to me was the heart of service I found in each of those elected officials who showed up. 

We discussed the pressing infrastructure issues facing their residents, including the recently secured $986,000 of federal funds requested in May, which was approved to repair a central waterline in Lonaconing (I later visited the repair of that line and the neighbor who was impacted). While our office is still fighting for FEMA funding for flood damage across the county, I know that resources will continue to be needed from multiple avenues.

But what was most meaningful to me is that our luncheon and recent conversations demonstrate what government should look like: different stakeholders coming together to address our community’s problems. Every American should have access to clean water, community resources and the infrastructure needed to thrive, and our office is working to deliver those things in @AlleganyCoMD - Maryland and across Mountain Maryland. ~A

In April, I visited the construction site of the @BGCWC_MD. Last Tuesday, I returned to see the final product of those visionary blueprints and met the amazing kids who now call the new building a second home. With the help of CEO & President Addie Nardi and her talented staff, I saw firsthand how these kids can benefit from the community-focused, educational environment the club provides outside of school hours.

Further, I witnessed how the close-knit Hagerstown community came together to help bring this dream into reality. After-school programs can change the trajectory of these kids’ lives. As a member of Congress, I will continue to work towards ensuring all our kids have the resources they need to be safe, to thrive, and to know that others care about their future. Kudos, and I look forward to my next visit. ~A

Our shared values compel us to fight for every child, parent and senior who needs a meal. No one in our community should have to worry where their next meal will come from.

As a farmer's daughter and only Maryland Representative on @HouseAgDems, I spent time this past week in Flintstone, MD at Robinette Farm. @FarmBureauMD Allegany County Farm Bureau President TR Robinette spoke with me about agricultural priorities for the upcoming “skinny farm bill,” including the need for greater agricultural research, the risks to livestock from the invasive screw worm, and combating the real challenges family farms are facing. 

The 2026 budget includes almost $24 billion in cuts from agriculture, but I am committed to passing a comprehensive farm bill that protects and empowers America’s farmers and stands up for our rural communities.

Sadly, $70 billion in recent cuts to Medicaid and reformulation of the reimbursements for hospitals threaten that lifeline — but I’ll keep fighting to make sure Western Maryland health providers can continue to provide these critical services.

For over a century, the people of Brunswick have depended on a water tank that has faithfully served the community—but time has taken its toll. With severe leaks threatening public health, water quality, and the financial stability of local families, it was clear that action was needed. That’s why I requested federal support for the Brunswick Reservoir, and I’m proud that $1,015,000 in funding has been approved.

This investment will replace the old facilities with a modern 1.25 million-gallon storage tank, reducing water loss, lowering costs, and ensuring every resident can count on safe, reliable water. Our communities deserve systems that protect their health and their future—and I’m honored to help deliver this critical support.

Honored to join Team Maryland in Congress to fight for Allegany and Garrett Counties after the devastating flooding.
